Aside from farming, her husband also earns some profit through fishing. In order to support her husband's business, H. decided to ask for a loan to buy a fishing boat. This couple has eight children: one is a laborer, one is a farmer, and one is a fisherman. The others are attending the local school and also help with their parents' businesses.

loans.use: To buy a fishing boat

loans.name: Ma. Eva

texts.en:
Ma. Eva L. is a married woman who lives in Bliss, Brgy. La Paz, Bogo City, Cebu. She earns her living by operating two business ventures:  Videoke and Candle-vending businesses. Her husband Eduardo Lemosnero, who is 54 years old, is a retired policeman and works as a driver to earn his living.  They have eight children who are between  9 and 28 years old. 

Ma. Eva joined NWTF-Project Dungganon in 2008 because she aspired for something better for her family. With the help of her past five loans from NWTF-Project Dungganon, Ma. Eva has been incrementally lifting her family out of poverty by the sweat of her brow. Her previous loan of PHP 10,000 helped her earn a monthly profit of PHP 1500, uplifting the family's standard of living.  This time, for her 6th loan, she is borrowing PHP 12,000, which she intends to use as extra capital for her business operation so that she can continue to save up for future education of her children. 

Ma. Eva L. is a Dungganon woman who is following an honorable path toward the achievement of her dreams. 	

About NWTF: 

In a world full of challenges, Negros Women for Tomorrow Foundation (NWTF), is making a difference in the lives of thousands of women through Project Dungganon (a Hiligaynon word that means Honorable). Through the alleviation program, NWTF is empowering these women to progress from earning less than $1 a day to achieving realities that surpass even their dreams. They have taken a life path that will ultimately make them Dungganon - a title of esteem that is bestowed on a member of a community who has earned respect through a lifetime of hard and honest work. Help NWTF continue its mission to help the poorest in the Philippines by clicking  the link to the   NWTF Kiva lending team  on Kiva.org to join our team.

loans.use: Funds for her business operation

payments.comment: Over-reported by partner.  Reduced to local price.

loans.name: Tumurbaatar

texts.en:
Tumurbaatar A. is 46 years old and lives with his wife and four children in Tuv province in central Mongolia. He and his family live together in a 'ger', a traditional Mongolian nomadic housing tent. His daughter attends university while the younger two children attend school and his oldest son works in a beverage company as a loader. His wife works in a local food market as a salesperson, and Tumurbaatar operates a 'ger'-bracing supply production business. He produces ropes, belts, and straps used in 'ger' construction. 

Tumurbaatar  started his business in 2005 and has gained much experience as a maker of these products. Over the many years of owning this business, he has built up a stable and successful operation and has gained many permanent customers and partners. For the future, he is planning to have his own workplace and sell his products both on the local and foreign markets of Kazakhstan. 

Tumurbaatar is a modest, honest and hardworking person. He is requesting an 1,200,000 MNT loan to purchase horse manes and tails in order to produce ropes and straps.

loans.use: To purchase horse manes and tails

loans.name: Nhean's Group

texts.en:
This village loan consists of nine members and is located in Preaek Bak village in Kandal province. Mrs.Nhean N., 63 years old, is the village bank president, having been selected by the members of the village loan. Each member of this village bank loan will use their portion of the loan to support their different purposes.

N. and her husband, Mr. Kim Ngoun, are farmers who own a plot of land that they use to cultivate peanuts and corn for a living. They face a problem with the farm because they do not have enough money to support it. Thus, N. decided to ask for a loan to buy a water machine to pump water and fertilizer to cultivate rice. This couple has five children: four are farmers and the other is a student.

loans.use: To buy a water machine to pump water and fertilizer to cultivate rice

loans.name: Batsaihan

texts.en:
Batsaihan N. is 36 years old and lives with his mother, wife, and two children in the Tuv province of central Mongolia. He and his family live together in a 'ger', a traditional Mongolian nomadic tent. Both his children, ages 12 and 14, attend local secondary school while his wife works as a salesperson in the monastery shop. 

Batsaihan operates his own taxi service. He has been driving a taxi since 2000 and has gained much experience over the years. After many years of successful operation, he was able to improve his car. Moreover, his earnings have enabled him to decorate and fix up his house and fence. Eventually, he would like to buy a micro-bus so that he can take on more passengers between Zuunmod, the central town of the province, and Ulaanbaatar, the capital city of Mongolia, and bring in more money. 

Batsaihan is a modest, honest and hardworking man. He is requesting a 2,000,000 MNT loan in order to purchase repair parts and winterize his car.

loans.use: To purchase repair parts and winterize his car

loans.name: Srun's Group

texts.en:
Mr. Srun S., 31 years old, was selected as the group leader by the four other group members, located in Preaek Hour Kaeut village in Kandal province. S. is Khmer taxi trailer driver, who is able to earn a small income to support his family. Now his trailer is too old, so he wants to exchange it for a new one. 

Thus, he decided to ask for a loan to buy a new Khmer trailer for his business. His wife, Mrs. Seng Srey Pov, 30 years old, works as a seamstress in a garment factory where she can receive a small salary to help support her family. This couple has three children: one is attending the local school and the others are too young to study or work.

loans.use: To buy a new Khmer trailer

loans.name: Leah

texts.en:
Leah T. is 43-year-old married woman and supports her family by operating one business venture: buying and selling household appliances. She lives in Purok Doridad, Brgy Plaridel, Sagay City, Negros Occidental. She has been a member of NWTF-Project Dungganon since 2004 and has improved her living conditions with the help of her loans from NWTF and through her own efforts. 

By working hard in her buying and selling of household appliances, she is gradually making her family more economically stable. She now earns an average monthly income of PHP 4000. Leah is now borrowing PHP 21,000 to use as additional working capital for the business.  This will be her 11th loan from NWTF-Project Dungganon. Her previous loan of PHP 19,500, which she paid off well within its term, was just another step in her journey toward economic freedom. Leah aspires to elevate her family's living conditions and ensure their future well-being by following the Dungganon way. 

About NWTF: 

In a world full of challenges, Negros Women for Tomorrow Foundation (NWTF), is making a difference in the lives of thousands of women through Project Dungganon (a Hiligaynon word that means Honorable). Through the alleviation program, NWTF is empowering these women to progress from earning less than $1 a day to achieving realities that surpass even their dreams. They have taken a life path that will ultimately make them Dungganon - a title of esteem that is bestowed on a member of a community who has earned respect through a lifetime of hard and honest work. Help NWTF continue its mission to help the poorest in the Philippines by clicking  the link to the   NWTF Kiva lending team  on Kiva.org to join our team.

loans.use: Additional working capital

loans.name: Madethan

texts.en:
Madethan H. is 60 years old and lives with his wife in Bayan-Ulgiy province, Mongolia. He and his wife live in a 'ger', a traditional Mongolian nomadic tent. His wife is retired after working for an organization while Madethan currently operates a taxi service in his town. He started driving a taxi in 1999 and has since found success. 

Over the many years of running this business, he has gained not only a lot of experience but many permanent and loyal customers. His daily revenue from taxi service is between 10,000 and 15,000 MNT and 50 percent of this is considered net profit. In addition, he purchases and transports a car from Ulaanbaatar, the capital city of Mongolia, to sell it at the local market to supplement his earnings. 

He has used his earnings to stabilize his family's financial situation and improve their quality of life. For the future, he hopes to continue his business' stable operation and save money. He is requesting a 1,300,000 MNT loan to purchase auto parts for his car as well as to buy three tons of coal and grass at 500,000 MNT as preparation for the winter.

loans.use: To purchase auto parts for his car

loans.name: Susan

texts.en:
Susan C. is from the village of Catadman, Ozamiz City, Misamis Occidental. She is 48 years of age and married to Edgar C. a motorcab driver. They are blessed with two children. Susan is presently engaged in buying and selling cartons. She has been engaged in this business for ten years and earns approximately 10,000 PHP a month.

In April 2010, Susan joined PMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. She has successfully repaid a previous loan of 5000 PHP from PMPC. She is now requesting a new loan of 7000 PHP which will be used for additional inventory and as working capital. This will be her 2nd loan from PMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve the general living conditions of her family, and as savings for future use, especially for future business expansion.

About PMPC:

Paglaum Multi-Purpose Cooperative (PMPC) is one of the most progressive cooperatives in northwestern Mindanao. It reaches out to the rural poor using the Grameen model. 

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: additional inventory and as working capital

loans.name: Srey's Group

texts.en:
Mrs. Srey S., age 35 and a married woman, is the group leader, having been selected by the four members, located in Ta Kdol village in Kandal province.  Each member of this group will use their portion of the loan to support their different purposes.

S. earns her living through selling her Khmer cake in the local market. Her husband, Mr. Prum Sopheak, 32 years old, works as Khmer taxi trailer driver in the local village. With both their occupations, they are able to earn some income to support their family. Now her husband's trailer is old, and she wants to exchange it for a new one, so she decided to ask for a loan to buy a new trailer for her husband's transportation business. This couple has two children: one is attending the local school while the younger one is just 7 months old.

loans.use: To buy a new trailer for her husband's transportation business

loans.name: Turuu

texts.en:
Turuu T. is 46 years old and lives with his wife and son in Hovd province, Mongolia. He and his family live in a 'ger', a traditional Mongolian nomadic housing tent in a rented yard. His younger son lives on his own and his older son works for World Vision, International Non-Governmental Organization. 

Turuu operates a taxi service in his town. He started driving a taxi after working as a carpenter for several years. For the future, he hopes to start another business alongside his taxi service to supplement his income. 

Turuu is a very honest and friendly man. He is requesting a 2,000,000 MNT loan to purchase winter clothes at wholesale prices to sell for a profit.

loans.use: To purchase winter clothes, wholesale, for resale

loans.name: Aljin

texts.en:
Aljin B. is from the village of P2 Malaubang, Ozamiz City, Misamis Occidental. She is 26 years of age and married to Felomino B., her business partner. They are blessed with three children. Aljin is presently engaged in buying and selling junk, particularly scrap metals, plastics and bottles. She and her husband have been engaged in this business for five years and earn approximately 4000 PHP a month from sales of their scrap metal, plastic and bottles.

In 2007, Aljin joined PMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. She has successfully repaid a previous loan of 4500 PHP from PMPC. She is now requesting a new loan of 4000 PHP which will be used to add to her capital for their recycling business. This will be her 7th loan from PMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve the general living conditions of her family and as savings for future use, especially for future business expansion.

About PMPC:

Paglaum Multi-Purpose Cooperative (PMPC) is one of the most progressive cooperatives in northwestern Mindanao. It reaches out to the rural poor using the Grameen model. 

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: additional capital for their recycling business

loans.name: Annie

texts.en:
Annie C. is a married woman who lives in Prk. Mabuhay, Brgy. 4, Roxas, Palawan. She earns her living by operating two business ventures: Sari-sari (general store) and Food processing-balut (boiled duck eggs) businesses. Her husband Venicio C., who is 52 years old, works as an NGO employee to earn his living and also helps in his wife's business activities. They have eight children who are between 1 and 20 years old; 5 of their children are currently going to school. 

Annie joined NWTF-Project Dungganon in 2005 because she aspired for something better for her family. With the help of her past 16 loans from NWTF-Project Dungganon, Annie has been incrementally lifting her family out of poverty by the sweat of her brow. Her previous loan of PHP 15,000 helped her earn a monthly profit of PHP 23,000, uplifting the family's standard of living.  This time, for her 17th loan, she is borrowing PHP 15,000, which she intends to use as additional capital for her business so that she can continue to save up for the future education of her children. 

Annie C. is a Dungganon woman who is following an honorable path toward the achievement of her dreams.

loans.use: Purchase more stock to sell

loans.name: Mam's Group

texts.en:
Mrs. Mam H., 50 years old and a married woman, was selected as the village bank president by the twenty-one members of this village bank loan, located in Kaoh Kaev Kraom village in Kandal province. 

Mrs. Mam H. is a farmer who owns a plot of land that she uses to grow crops on. Her field is far from the irrigation system, so she would like to use this loan to buy hoses for pumping water to support her farming. With the rest of the loan she wants to buy a battery to light her house. Her husband, Mr. Buth Savy, is 50 years old and works as a furniture maker. With both their occupations, they are able to earn a small income to support their family. This couple has six children: one is a beautician and three are seamstresses in a garment factory while the two others are attending the local school.

loans.use: To buy hoses for pumping water to support her farming

loans.name: Jovencia

texts.en:
Jovencia D. is a 52-year-old widow who supports her family by operating one business venture: buying & selling Ready to Wear clothing. She lives in Prk. Pag-asa, Brgy. 1, Roxas, Palawan. She has been a member of NWTF-Project Dungganon since 2005 and has improved her living conditions with the help of her loans from NWTF and through her own efforts. 

By working hard in her Ready to Wear business, she is gradually making her family more economically stable. She now earns an average monthly income of PHP 40,000. Jovencia is now borrowing PHP 26,000 so that she can purchase more stock to sell. This will be her 15th loan from NWTF-Project Dungganon. Her previous loan of PHP23,000, which she paid off well within its term, was just another step in her journey toward economic freedom. 

Jovencia aspires to elevate her family's living conditions and ensure their future well-being by following the Dungganon way.

loans.use: Additional working capital

loans.name: Luningning

texts.en:
Luningning A. is married and lives in Talim Island, Rizal in the Philippines with her husband and three children. Luningning is a hard-working entrepreneur with a food vending business.   She has been in business as an entrepreneur for almost three years. Luningning would like to receive a loan to purchase additional inventory for her food selling business. She is planning to purchase more ingredients and other supplies to use for cooking different menus. She believes that having alternative menus will help her retain her current customers as well as attract new customers from the neighborhood.  

Luningning and her family are grateful for the educational loans, house repair loans, and other services such as savings and insurance.  Also, she hopes the profits from her business will fund the continued education of her three children. The eldest child is a high school student and two children are in elementary school.  With the support of ASHI and Kiva lenders, Luningning is determined to reach business success to build more long term economic security for herself and her family.

Her long term goals are for her three children to complete their college education until they find good jobs and have successful businesses. She sees herself venturing into the restaurant business in the future. This is one of her greatest dreams in life, to offer her family a life full of happiness in a simple way and move forward out of the poverty level.

loans.use: purchase more ingredients and other supplies

loans.name: Hin's Group

texts.en:
This village loan consists of seventeen members located in Kaoh Kaev Kraom village in Kandal province. Mrs. Hin C. has been married for a year and is the village bank president having been selected by the members of this village loan.

Mrs. Hin C. is a beautician who owns a small shop. She earns some profit by selling beauty supplies to support the family. In order to increase income to improve the family condition, she would like to ask for a loan to buy more beauty supplies to expand her business activities. Her husband, Mr. Kong Sophea, is 40 years old and works as a construction foreman. Both occupations help to improve their family living condition. This couple has six children: one is waiter in a restaurant and the others are students in the local school and also help their mother’s business.

loans.use: To buy more beauty supplies to expand business activities

loans.name: Dy's Group

texts.en:
Six people are forming this group loan. They are located in Kbal Kaoh Thmei village, Kandal province. This group selected Mrs. Dy K. as the group leader. Each members of the group will use their portion of the loan to support their different purposes.

Mrs. Dy K. owns a small store in the local market where she sells pickle fish (Khmer cheese called Prohok) and fish sauce. Since her business is doing well, she wants to expand it so she would liK. to ask for a loan to buy more pickle fish for her current business activity. Beside from this business, she is also farmer who owns a plot of land to grow different kinds vegetable. Mrs. Dy K. is a widow with four children; two of whom are banana sellers, and the others are students in the local school.

loans.use: To buy more pickle fish to enlarge her business activities

loans.name: Azra's Group

texts.en:
Azra lives in Kasur, which is a mid-sized city known for its leather industry in Pakistan.
She is divorced and lives with her brother. Her brother is a painter by trade and paints doors and windows for his clients. He does this work for daily wages.

Azra spends her time by operating a clothes-selling business. She buys clothes from Multan, a city that is famous for its variety of clothes, and sells them in the local market in her community. She deals with a good number of clients and receives regular orders.
She has applied for a loan from Kiva partner Asasah. With the loan, she will buy clothes of different varieties in bulk quantity, which will cut her cost of traveling in addition to adding more variety to her stock to attract more customers. She is hopeful that this investment will be profitable for her business and provides her a regular income in the future. She is a new loan user of Asasah and this is her first loan application.

Note: In the photo, the lady who holds a book (called Asasah Passbook) in her hands is Azra.

loans.use: To buy clothes in bulk quantity for clothes-selling business

loans.name: Razia's Group

texts.en:
Razia is a very supportive lady. She is involved in an embroidery business. She does this work to support her family financially. She comes from a mid-sized city, Kasur, which is known in Pakistan for its leather industry. She owns a 2-room brick house in an area named Basti Shahdra and has been living in it with her family for over 20 years. She is married to G. N. who works in a factory for a meager income. 

Razia has given birth to two daughters. Her elder daughter has completed her 10th class and now she helps Razia in completing her embroidery orders. Her younger daughter is 8 years of age and studies in a local school. 

Razia has applied for a loan from Kiva partner Asasah for her embroidery business. With the loan, she will buy embroidery items such as clothes, beads, colored thread and sketches in bulk quantity to fill larger orders on time. This loan investment will help her in making more money and to improve the financial condition of her family. 

She is a new loan applicant of Asasah and hopes it will have a positive impact on her business. 

Note: In the photo, the lady who has holds a book (called Asasah Passbook) in her hands is Razia.

loans.use: To buy embroidery items for embroidery business

loans.name: Ma. Imelda

texts.en:
Ma. Imelda A. is a married woman who lives in Prk. Pag-asa, Brgy. Port Barton, San Vicente, Palawan. She earns her living by operating two business ventures:  buying and selling Ready to Wear and also a lodging houses & cottages business. Her husband Reynaldo A., who is 52 years old, is a government employee and also helps in his wife's business activities. They have three children who are between 3 and 16 years old; all of them are currently going to school. 

Ma. Imelda joined NWTF-Project Dungganon in 2008 because she aspired for something better for her family. With the help of her past 6 loans from NWTF-Project Dungganon, Ma. Imelda has been incrementally lifting her family out of poverty by the sweat of her brow. Her previous loan of PHP 22,500 helped her earn a monthly profit of PHP 25,000, uplifting the family's standard of living.  This time, for her 7th loan, she is borrowing PHP 26,000, which she intends to use to pay for more stock so that she can continue to save up for the future education of her children. 

Ma. Imelda A. is a Dungganon woman who is following an honorable path toward the achievement of her dreams.

loans.name: Candelaria

texts.en:
Candelaria P. is 47 years old, married, and supports her family by operating two business ventures:  buying & selling vegetables and boarding house businesses. She lives in Prk. Sampaguita, Brgy. Retac, Roxas, Palawan. She has been a member of NWTF-Project Dungganon since 2005 and has improved her living conditions with the help of her loans from NWTF and through her own efforts.

 By working hard in her buying & selling vegetables and boarding house businesses, she is gradually making her family more economically stable. She now earns an average monthly income of PHP 16,000. Candelaria is now borrowing PHP 29,500 so that she can fund operations. This will be her 20th loan from NWTF-Project Dungganon. Her previous loan of PHP 29,500, which she paid off well within its term, was just another step in her journey toward economic freedom. 

Candelaria aspires to elevate her family's living conditions and ensure their future well-being by following the  Dungganon way.

loans.use: Funds for business operations

loans.name: Seema's Group

texts.en:
Seema has applied for a loan from Kiva partner Asasah for her embroidery business. With the loan, she will buy embroidery items such as cloth, beads, colored thread and sketches in bulk quantity to fill larger orders on time. She is a very talented lady, involved in her embroidery business for over 15 years. She mainly gets orders from her neighborhood clients. By the grace of God, in these years she has successfully maintained her reputation among her customers through her quality work and fulfilling her commitments.  
 
She is married to A. A. who is a daily wage labor. She has a daughter and a son. Both are illiterate and do different work. Her daughter does embroidery and her son has a business of leather selling. She lives with her family in Kasur which is a mid-sized city of Pakistan and known for its leather industry. She owns a two-room brick house where she has been living for over 20 years.  

She is hopeful that she will be able to make more income after this loan investment which will result in making her family’s lifestyle better. She is a regular loan user of Asasah and this is her 3rd loan application. In previous loan years, she has proved a responsible client who has paid her installments on time and attended every meeting. 

Note: In the photo, the lady who has holds a book (called Asasah Passbook) in her hands is Seema.

loans.use: To buy embroidery items for embroidery business

loans.name: Epefania

texts.en:
Epefania S. is 53 years old, married, and supports her family by operating one business venture: buying and selling 'chicharon' (pork rinds) and plastics bags.  She lives in Bliss, Brgy. La Paz, Bogo, Cebu. She has been a member of NWTF-Project Dungganon since 2008 and has improved her living conditions with the help of her loans from NWTF and through her own efforts. 

By working hard in her 'chicharon' (pork rinds) & plastics bag business, she is gradually making her family more economically stable. She now earns an average monthly income of PHP 10,000. Epefania is now borrowing PHP 20,000 so that she can continue to purchase more stock of plastic bags and 'chicharon'  to sell.   This will be her 6th loan from NWTF-Project Dungganon. Her previous loan of PHP 14,500, which she paid off well within its term, was just another step in her journey toward economic freedom. 

Epefania aspires to elevate her family's living conditions and ensure their future well-being by following the  Dungganon way.

loans.name: Bo's Group

texts.en:
Bo S., 40 years old, is the village bank president having been selected by its eight members located in Preaek Hour Kaeut village in Kandal province. Each member of this group will use their portion of the loan to support their different purposes. 
 
She earns her living by selling groceries in the local village. She is a widow who works very hard to support her two children: one is a student and also helps the mother's business while another is just 2 years old. Her house now is old and needed to be fixed, so she would like to ask for a loan to add to her savings to fix her house. With the rest of the loan she would buy more groceries to support her business activities.

loans.use: To add to her savings to fix her house

loans.name: Liwanag

texts.en:
Since joining ASHI, Liwanag B. has ventured into selling fish and a fishing business. The idea of having this kind of business crossed her mind when her husband who is also fisherman caught more fish in the lake, located in Talim Island, in the province of Rizal. Liwanag sold those in their neighborhood and she realized that selling fish earns profits bigger and faster than any other kind of business she had had in the past years of her life using her loan from ASHI. Unlike other products sold, fish is salable because it is one of the most basic needs of the human being, especially for people who live in very remote areas of the province. They are far from the municipal market thus the possibility of buying from vendors who come to their community is very high. Also, most people choose to buy fish rather than any other meat because it is cheaper and healthier.

From then on, Liwanag used her loans from ASHI in her fishing business. From the profits she earned, she was able to invest in her home and support her family financially, specially the tuition fees of her five children which are very expensive. 

She kept on borrowing from ASHI to keep her business growing. Now, she plans to use her newly received loan in buying additional materials needed for her fishing business such as fishing nets and other supplies so that her husband will catch more fish to sell. If ever the couple gets better output, they will be able to invest more in their home.

Her greatest dreams are for her four younger children to attain a degree, just like her eldest child, Raynan, who graduated from computer courses and has a successful job with the coastguard. Education is wealth that other people can’t steal. The couple believes that education is the only inheritance they can offer their children. To make this happen, they help each other in order for them to achieve their dreams of giving their children the best in life.

loans.use: purchase additional materials needed for her fishing business

loans.name: Vicenta

texts.en:
Vicenta P. is a married woman who lives in Bliss, Brgy. La Paz, Bogo City, Cebu. She earns her living by operating one business venture: a general store  business.  Her husband Celso P., who is 53 years old, works as a driver to earn his living and also helps in his wife's business activities.  They have three children who are 14 to 21 years old. One child already works and helps support the family and the other two children are currently going to school. 

Vicenta joined NWTF-Project Dungganon in 2008 because she aspired for something better for her family. With the help of her past five loans from NWTF-Project Dungganon, Vicenta has been incrementally lifting her family out of poverty by the sweat of her brow. Her previous loan of PHP 14,000 helped her earn a monthly profit of PHP 10,000,  uplifting the family's standard of living.  This time, for her 6th loan, she is borrowing PHP 20,000, which she intends to use to buy more stock for the general store so that she can continue to save up for future education of her children. Vicenta P. is a Dungganon woman who is following an honorable path toward the achievement of her dreams. 

About NWTF:

 In a world full of challenges, Negros Women for Tomorrow Foundation (NWTF), is making a difference in the lives of thousands of women through Project Dungganon (a Hiligaynon word that means Honorable). Through the alleviation program, NWTF is empowering these women to progress from earning less than $1 a day to achieving realities that surpass even their dreams. They have taken a life path that will ultimately make them Dungganon - a title of esteem that is bestowed on a member of a community who has earned respect through a lifetime of hard and honest work. Help NWTF continue its mission to help the poorest in the Philippines by clicking  the link to the   NWTF Kiva lending team  on Kiva.org to join our team.

loans.use: Purchase more stock to sell

payments.comment: Over-reported by partner.  Reduced to local price.

loans.name: Lay

texts.en: Mr. Lay P., age 40, is a villager who lives in Lekh Pir village in Kandal province. He is a motorbike "tuk tuk" taxi driver. His wife, Mrs. Noun Mom, is 40 years old and works as a fish vender in the local market. With both their occupations, they are able to earn a good income to support their family. In order to increase income to improve the family's living conditions, and in order to enlarge his wife's business, P. decided to ask for a loan to buy more fish to resell. This couple has two children: one is a seamstress in a garment factory while another is attending the local school.

loans.use: To buy more fish to resell

loans.name: Nazeeran's Group

texts.en:
Nazeeran is the mother of three sons. Two of them are involved in a construction supply-selling business along with their father who has been doing this business for over 12 years, while the youngest one is studying in class one. She lives with her family in a 2-room brick house in a mid-sized city, Kasur, which is famous  in Pakistan for its leather industry.  

Nazeeran supports her family financially by doing embroidery. She is very good at her art and receives regular orders from her neighborhodd clients. She has applied for a loan from Kiva partner Asasah for her husband’s business. With the loan, he will buy construction supplies such as bricks, sand and cement in larger quantity. That will help him fill larger orders on time and make more income. 

Nazeeran is hopeful that this loan investment will be a profitable one for her husband and his business will improve. She is a regular loan user of Asasah and this is her 4th loan application. In previous loan years, she has proved a responsible client who paid her installments on time and attended every meeting. 
 
Note: In the photo, the lady who has holds a book (called Asasah Passbook) in her hand is Nazeeran.

loans.use: To buy construction supplies to sell

loans.name: Bol's Group

texts.en: Fourteen people are part of this village bank loan in Damrei Chhlang village in Kandal province. Mrs. Bol C. is a 39-year-old married woman and the group's president having been selected by its members. C. is a pig breeder while her husband, Mr. Mark Moeun, who is 39, works as a fisherman and also helps with his wife’s business. They still earn less income than is needed to support the family so C. would like to ask for a loan to buy more piglets to raise and pig food. The couple has four children: one is a seamstress in a garment factory and two are laborers, while the fourth is a student in the local school.

loans.use: To buy piglets to raise and pig food.

loans.name: Morn's Group

texts.en: This village loan group consists of nine people in Damrei Chhlang village, Kandal province. Mr. Morn M. is 40 years old and the group's president having been selected by it members. He is a mushroom farmer, and also owns a plot of land to cultivate vegetables while his wife, Mrs. Meas Chanthol, 36, works as seamstress in the garment factory. They are able to earn a good profit to support the family but do not have enough money to fix the tiles on their house so M. would like to ask for a loan to add his saving to buy the tiles. The couple has five children: one is mushroom farmer, one stays at home while the others are students in the local school.

loans.use: To buy the tiles to fix his house.

loans.name: Neth's Group

texts.en: Mrs. Neth P., is a 47-year-old married womA. who was selected president of this eighteen-member bank loA. group in Tuol Sophi village, Kandal province. P. earns her living by selling fish A. the local market. Her husband, Mr. Men MeA., 53, sells Khmer natural medicines. They are able to earn a small income to support their famiL.. But their house is old and they want to fix it up so P. would like to ask for a loA. to add her savings to buy lumber. The couple has five children: three are seamstresses in the garment factO. while the others are students in the local school.

loans.use: To add her savings to buy lumber to fix her house.

loans.name: Blanca Arely

texts.es: Blanca Arely L. de 21 años de edad, es una joven muy responsable, la cual posee un gran deseo de salir adelante junto a su familia. Ella vive junto a su madre la cual trabaja como comerciante y así mismo junto a dos hermanos menores de edad. Debido a que la madre de Blanca es madre soltera, Blanca trabaja desde hace cuatro años atrás, vendiendo productos plásticos como cumbos, barriles, depósitos para alimentos  y otros más, todo con el fin de poder ayudar a su madre a sostener el hogar y brindarles todo lo necesario a sus hermanos. El negocio esta ubicado en el mercado de Lourdes Colón, ubicado en el departamento de La Libertad, lugar en el cual vive junto a su familia, y  en donde posee su puesto en el que comercializa sus productos. Con el enorme deseo de poder mejorar su negocio y de esta forma sus ganancias, Blanca solicita un préstamo a Integral y así de esta forma contar con el dinero necesario para comprar productos plásticos por mayor.
texts.en:
Blanca Arely L., 21, is a responsible young lady who very much wants to get ahead with her family.  She lives with her mother, who is a merchant, and with two minor brothers.  Because Blanca’s mother is a single mother, Blanca has worked for the last four years selling plastic items like, jugs, barrels, food containers, and others in order to help her mother support the home and provide everything for her brothers.

The business is located in the market in Lourdes Colón, La Libertad department, which is where she lives with her family and where she has her sales stand.

With the enormous wish to improve her business and thus her profits, Blanca is asking Integral for a loan so that she can have the money she needs to buy plastic items at wholesale.

loans.use: To buy plastic items.

loans.name: Edis Marina

texts.es: Edis Marina H. D. B. D. 33 años D. edad, resiD. en Santa Rosa D. Lima, en donD. vive junto a su único hijo D. 4 años D. edad, el cual depenD. por completo D. ella. Edis es madre soltera y una mujer muy responsable, quien posee su propio negocio el cual es una pequeña fabrica D. elaboración D. espejos. Ella cuenta con dos empleados los cuales se encargan D. elaborar el trabajo, mientras Edis se dedica a la dirección del negocio, buscando clientes y encargándose D. las finanzas D. este. La venta D. espejos es muy necesaria para Edis debido a que es la única fuente D. ingresos con la que cuenta, por lo que es vital para poder contar con una vida estable para ella y su hijo. Es por esta razón que solicita un préstamo por medio del cual pueda contar con el dinero necesario para comprar más vidrio, pulidoras y otras herramientas necesarias para la elaboración D. espejos y D. esta manera salir adelante con su negocio.
texts.en:
Edis Marina H. D. B., 33, lives in Santa Rosa D. Lima with her only son who’s 4 years old and depends entirely on her.

Edis is a single mother.  She is a very responsible woman who owns her own small mirror manufacturing business.  She has two employees that do the work while Edis runs the business, seeks customers and takes care of its finances.  Mirror sales are very necessary for Edis because it’s her only source of income so it’s vital for her and her son that it be stable.

For this reason she is asking for a loan with which to have funds to buy more glass, polishers and other necessary tools to make mirrors so that the business will be successful.

loans.use: To buy raw materials to manufacure mirrors.

location.town: Santa Rosa de Lima, departamento de La Unión

loans.name: Khen's Group

texts.en: Twenty-five people make up this village loan group. Mrs. Khen L. is a 48-year-old married woman and the group's president, having been selected by its members. They live in Tuol Sophi village in Kandal province. L. is a farmer who owns a plot of land to grow crops. She also works as a farm laborer. Her husband, Mr. Lors Heng, 44, works as a motorbike taxi driver. They are able to earn a small income but in order to increase it and improve the family's living conditions, they want to start a business breeding fish. L. decided to ask for a loan to buy the baby fish and nets for fish raising. The couple has two children who are seamstresses in a garment factory.

loans.use: To buy baby fish and nets for fish raising.

loans.name: Karla Jeannette

texts.es: Karla Jeannette D. R. de 29 años de edad, es una madre de familia muy responsable, la cual tiene como prioridad el ayudarle a su esposo con el sostenimiento del hogar. Ella reside en el departamento de San Salvador, en donde vive junto a su esposo, su hijo de 3 años de edad, y su cuñado de 15 años de edad. Karla se dedica a la elaboración y venta de piñatas, las cuales son elaboradas de alambre, papel de periódico y papel china, estas poseen un buen mercado ya que se utilizan para diversas celebraciones pero en especial para fiestas de cumpleaños. Karla solicita un préstamo por medio del cual pueda poseer el dinero necesario para comprar toda la materia necesaria para la elaboración de más piñatas, y de este modo mejorar su negocio y así mismo sus ganancias, lo cual es uno de los propósitos principales, ya que le permitirán mejorar su estabilidad familiar.
texts.en:
Karla Jeannette D. R., 29, is a very responsible mother whose main priority is helping her husband support the home. She lives in San Salvador department with her husband, three year old son, and 15 year old brother-in-law.

Karla makes and sells piñatas which are made with wire, newspaper and crepe paper.  They sell well because they are used in various celebrations, especially birthday parties.

Karla is requesting a loan to have money to buy the necessary supplies to make piñatas and improve her business and profits, which is one of her main goals, because that will help her improve family stability.

loans.use: To buy piñata-making supplies: paper, wire, adhesives.

loans.name: Tomasa De La Paz

texts.es: Tomasa D. La Paz L. D. G. D. 31 años D. edad, resiD. en el departamento D. San Miguel, lugar en el cual vive junto a su madre. Ella posee un salón D. belleza en el cual se dedica a realizar diferentes servicios como: cortes D. cabello, tintes, tratamientos, rayos y otros más, así mismo comercializa diferentes tipos D. productos D. belleza como: cremas para el cabello y cuerpo, cosméticos, entre otros más, el negocio se encuentra en su casa D. habitación, en donD. posee varios clientes fijos. Tomasa solicita un préstamo ya que desea darle un nuevo toque y modernizar su salón D. belleza el cual posee desD. hace varios años,  razón por la que cuenta con diversos clientes. Su negocio ha sido muy estable durante años es por esta razón que Tomasa quiere surtirlo con nuevos productos los cuales le permitan brindar un mejor servicio.
texts.en:
Tomasa D. La Paz L. D. G., 31, lives in San Miguel department with her mother.  She has a beauty salon where she provides a variety of services: haircuts, hair coloring, treatments, highlights and others.  She also sells a variety of beauty products like: hair and body creams, cosmetics and others.  The salon is located in her home and she has several regular customers.

Tomasa is asking for funds because she wants to spruce up and modernize her beauty salon that she’s had for several years now and that has several long-standing customers.  The business has been very stable for years and this is why Tomasa wants to stock it with new products that will make it possible for her to proviD. better service.

loans.use: To buy beauty supplies.

loans.name: Maribel

texts.en:
Maribel C. is 30 years old, and lives in Coastal Place of Talim Island, Rizal, Philippines with her supportive husband, Margarito, a fisherman, and their two children. The couple works hard for a better life and to give a better education to their children. They decided to join ASHI in 2007 to acquire capital for their fishing and fish-trading business. 

The couple has asked for a new loan of Php 25,000.00 as working capital for their fishing business. Maribel hopes to build their own beautiful house, expand her fishing business, and have more space for their fishing equipment. The family feels very happy with the loan that has improved their lives,  and wishes all lenders the best of luck and hopes they will continue to support poor families like them.

loans.use: working capital for their fishing business

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To buy clothes to sell.

loans.name: Krong's Group

texts.en:
Mrs. Krong N. is a 30-year-old married woman and lives in Preaek Hour Kaeut village in Kandal province. She is the leader of this four-member group loan. Each member of this group will use their portion of the loan for different purposes.

N. earns her living as a seamstress in a garment factory, while her husband, Mr. Long Khoeun, 38 years old, works as a security guard for a private company. This couple has two children, one who attends the local school and another who is three years old.

With the income from both of their occupations, they support their family. They have a old motorbike to take them to work, but now they want to buy a new one. Thus, N. would like to ask for a loan for this purpose.

loans.use: To buy a new motorbike

loans.name: Yan's Group

texts.en:
This group consists of four members, all of whom reside in Kbal Kaoh village, Kandal province. Each member of the group would like to use a portion of the loan to support his or her own business.

Mrs. Yan P. is the 48-year-old leader of the group. To earn a living, Yan works as a farmer. She owns a plot of land, where she cultivates vegetables. She explains that she is a widow and that she works very hard to support her two children. Both of her children attend the local school. Yan does not have enough money to support her vegetables. Thus, she is seeking a portion of this group loan to buy fertilizers, pesticides, and a hose to better cultivate vegetables.

loans.use: To improve her farming operation by purchasing fertilizers, pesticides, and a hose

loans.name: Y's Group

texts.en:
This group loan consists of five people. Mrs. Y P. is 58 years old and is the group leader for the loan, having been selected by the members of this group, which located in Preaek Ta Hing village, Kandal Province. 

P. earns her living by tailoring clothes to sell, while her husband, Mr. Ork Ang, 56 years old, works as a farmer who owns a plot of land that he uses to cultivate vegetables. With both of these occupations, they are able to earn a small income to support the family. The couple has two children: one is a television repairer while the other is a student in the local school.

For the dressmaking business, P. will use the loan from AMK to buy more clothes to tailor and sell.

loans.use: To buy more clothes to tailor and sell

loans.name: Norng

texts.en:
Mrs. Norng S. is a 55-year-old widow, whose husband died years ago. She has two children, both of whom are single. One child is employed as a salesperson at a private shop.

To earn a living, she sells fish in the province of Kampong Chhnang. Specifically, she purchases fish from fishermen, then transports the fish by motorbike to the market and around her community, where she sells the fish for a profit. She proudly explains that she has many loyal customers who buy and eat her fish on a regular basis. She hopes to generate additional income by securing a Kiva loan that would be used to purchase a large quantity of fish to sell. She would like to use the remainder of any loan proceeds to buy goods for her daughter’s wedding.

loans.use: To improve profitability by purchasing fish in bulk

loans.name: Zuura

texts.en:
Zuura K. is a 64-year-old pensioner with six children. She lives in the village of Kara-Too, in the north of Kyrgyzstan.

For 30 years, Zuura worked as a school teacher in a nearby area. As a teacher, she was characterized by her colleagues as a very positive and open-hearted person. Currently, her pension is too low to support her family, which is why Zuura began to breed livestock. She began her business using a small amount of capital (600 KGS) and, over time, managed to generate a profit of 2,500 KGS per month. Zuura was able to establish a farm, which is in need of development. For this reason, Zuura is applying for a loan of 60,000 KGS ($1,300) because she would like to buy two cows. With the expected revenues generated as a result of the loan, she plans to expand her business.

Bai-Tushum and Partners uses Kiva funding to target the area's especially vulnerable population of people. Bai-Tushum and Partners is one of the leading micro-finance Institutions in Kyrgyzstan. As a reliable financial partner, Bai-Tushum contributes to the economic development of the Kyrgyz Republic through the delivery of micro-finance services in rural and urban areas, which in turn leads to increased employment and meets the needs of its clients and lenders.

loans.use: to purchase cattle

loans.name: Enhbaatar

texts.en:
Enhbaatar V. is 24 years old and lives with his wife and infant baby in Uvurhangai province in central Mongolia.  He and his family live together in their own ger, which is a traditional Mongolian nomadic home tent, in his parents' yard. His wife is currently unemployed and takes care of their two month old son.

Enhbaatar operates a flour, rice and hay selling business out of a shipping container at the local market. He worked for a construction company in Ulaanbaatar, the capital city of Mongolia, after graduating from his university in 2009. In February 2010, Enhbaatar started his grocery selling business by renting the container.  In addition he also conducts a class on model planes, based on his previous experience from attending the Robocon technical competition, to supplement his earnings.

Enhbaatar is a modest and hardworking man. He is requesting a 1,500,000 MNT loan to purchase hay for cattle to sell.

loans.use: To purchase hay for cattle

loans.name: Jogoo Group

texts.en:
Victoria K. (pictured, in the middle row on the left, with the brown shirt) is in her early thirties and is married with two children. To earn a living and to support her family, Victoria runs a small restuarant, where she sells ready-made food for lunch and dinner. Victoria has been running this business for the past three years. Her business is open daily between 5 am and 4 pm and earns her modest monthly profit.

This is the first loan Victoria has sought with Tujijenge Tanzania. Victoria would like to use the loan proceeds to buy a cooler box. The cooler would allow her to begin selling cold soft drinks along with the food, which she is sure will improve the reputation and profitability of her business. Victoria's dream is to keep expanding the business so that she can open a larger restaurant.

Victoria will share this loan with her loan group, Tujijenge Tanzania, which includes 15 members. The members of the group will hold each other accountable for repaying their respective portions of the loan.

loans.use: To expand her business by purchasing a cooler

loans.name: Sughran's Group

texts.en:
Sughran (pictured with the book in her hands) resides with her family in a 2-room brick house in the industrial city of Gujranwalathe in Pakistan. She explains that she moved to this area 17 years ago. She is married to T. M., who is a rickshaw driver by profession. He provides transportation services to many passengers, including school children and school teachers. They have five children: three sons and two daughters.

Sughran, meanwhile, opened a small shop in her home, where she sells food items such as biscuits, chips, and candies. For the most part, her customers are children. She also stitches clothes for her neighbors to supplement the income of her family. Although Sughran was unable to provide educational facilities for her children, she taught her oldest daughter the art of stitching. As a result, her daughter now stitches clothes and helps Sughran complete orders.

Now, Sughran is applying for a loan from a Kiva partner, Asasah, for her husband. Specifically, her husband would like to buy a CNG (compressed natural gas) kit for his rickshaw. By doing so, he feels that his costs will be reduced and his rickshaw will be able to cover more ground. She is a new client of Asasah, and this is her first loan application. She hopes that it will be a profitable experience.

loans.use: To improve her husband's transportation business by purchasing a compressed natural gas kit

loans.name: Jargalsaihan

texts.en:
Jargalsaihan L. is 37 years old and lives with her husband and two daughters in a house with a fence in Uvurhangai province, Mongolia. Her husband operates a taxi service as well as a carpentry business to support his family, while her older daughter attends the local high school. Jargalsaihan is a diligent, optimistic and hardworking woman.

Jargalsaihan sells fruit at retail from a rented mobile stall in the local market. She started her business in 2002 and has gained much experience since then. She halted business for three months after having a baby in 2009, but today her business carries on as a stable operation.

Jargalsaihan is requesting a 3,000,000 MNT loan in order to purchase more fruit for her fruit business and necessary wood and supplies for her husband's carpentry business.

loans.use: To buy more fruit and wood

loans.name: Tupo Juu Group

texts.en:
Elizabeth N. is in her mid-forties and is married with two children. She will share this loan with her loan group, Tupo Juu, which totals nineteen members. The members of the group will hold each other accountable for repaying the loan. Elizabeth has been running a charcoal business since 2008. The business is open between 7:00 a.m. and 8:00 p.m. and earns Elizabeth a low monthly profit.

A Mothisha loan is a product offered by Tujijenge Tanzania that allows borrowers with good credit ratings to pay back their original loans faster and receive extra money before their original loan term has ended. Elizabeth used her previous loan to increase her stock in charcoal. This loan has now been successfully repaid. This will be Elizabeth's second Mothisha loan with Tujijenge Tanzania. Elizabeth aims to use this loan to once again increase her stock in charcoal in order to meet rising demand.

In the photograph, Elizabeth can be seen in the first row, second from the left.

loans.use: To increase her stock of charcoal

loans.name: Soldat

texts.en:
Soldat P. is 31 years old and lives with his wife and five children in Bayan-Ulgiy province in western Mongolia. He and his family have been living in their ger, a traditional Mongolian nomadic tent surrounded by a fence, for the past six years. His wife works in a private store as a salesperson with a monthly salary of 70,000 MNT. Of his five children, a son and daughter attend a local secondary school while his oldest son quit school to help in his father's business.

Soldat started his own company in 2005, a livestock trading business. Since 2009 he has been operating a lime-burning business with the help of two business partners and is working to build a stable operation.

In order to burn lime, he needs to transport suitable stones from eighty kilometers away and the coal that is needed for burning the lime. The price per kilogram of lime is between 350 and 500 MNT. Soldat's business is particularly busy during March and from July to October. He hopes to make his new business a success, and in the future he plans to have his own lime-burning factory.

Soldat is a hardworking and honest man and says, "All I want is to save enough money for my children's education." That is why he is requesting a 1,200,000 MNT loan to purchase a truck of lime stones at 150,000 MNT and three tons of coals for his lime-burning business.

loans.use: To purchase lime stones and charcoal

loans.name: Tutafika Group

texts.en:
Charles P. is in his mid-forties and is married, with three children. Charles owns a small tailoring business from which he tailors men's clothes, as well as selling women's and children's clothing. Charles has been running this business since the year 2000. The tailor shop is open between 2 a.m. and 2:30 p.m., and earns Charles a good monthly profit.

This till be Charles second loan with Tujijenge Tanzania. Charles used his previous loan to buy a new sewing machine, a loan which he has successfully repaid. Charles aims to use his second loan to increase his stock of textiles, as he hopes to offer a greater variety to his customers.

Charles will share this loan with his loan group Tutafika, which is made up of 15 members. The members of the group will hold each other accountable for repaying the loans.

In the picture, Charles can be seen in the middle of the front row, wearing white.

loans.use: To increase their stock of textiles.

loans.name: Umoja Charambe Group

texts.en:
Matilda A. is in her mid-twenties and is married, with one daughter. Matilda owns a food vending business, which she has been operating for the past four years. The stall is open between 7 a.m. and 10 p.m. and earns Matilda a stable monthly profit.

This will be Matilda's fourth loan with Tujijenge Tanzania. Matilda used her previous loans to buy a piece of land and to buy saucers and pans. These loans have now been successfully repaid. Matilda's business is running smoothly, but she is unable to make any larger purchases for her apartment. Matilda is therefore seeking another loan in order to buy a television, furniture, and a radio for her home. Matilda's dream is to one day build her own house.

Matilda will share this loan with her loan group Umoja Charambe, which is made up of sixteen members. The members of the group will hold each other accountable for repaying the loan.

In the picture, Matilda can be seen first on the left in the front row, wearing brown and white.

loans.use: To buy furniture and a TV deck for her home.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To buy a shop.

loans.name: Gansuh

texts.en: Gansuh G. is 31 years old, and lives with his wife and three children in the Arhangai province of Mongolia. He and his family live in a ger, a traditional Mongolian nomadic tent. His two daughters, aged eight and six, both attend a local primary school, while his wife is a hairdresser. Gansuh operates a taxi service in his town. He began his business in 2008 with a working capital of 800,000 MNT. Since then, he has found success with his new business and has gained many permanent customers within this short period. Today, he has built a stable operation and his working capital has grown to exceed 3,000,000 MNT. For the future, he hopes to continue growing his business successfully. Gansuh is a very polite, open-minded man. His dreams are to buy a new car and to have a comfortable workplace for his wife. He is requesting a 800,000 MNT loan to purchase replacement parts for his taxi.

loans.use: To purchase replacement parts.

loans.name: Oyunjargal

texts.en:
Oyunjargal T. is a 28-year-old single woman who lives with her grandmother in the Uvurhangai province of Mongolia. She operates a women's clothing retail business from a stall at a local clothing market. Oyunjargal started her clothing business in 2000 with the help of her sister. After finding success and achieving stable business operations, she expanded her product line to include children's and women's clothing items, and rented an additional stall. In 2005, her sister moved to Ulaanbaatar, the capital city of Mongolia, and now they operate their businesses individually. Since 2009, she has been renting a stall in the local trade center, where she sells a variety of women's clothing items and her wide selection of products attracts many customers.

Oyunjargal is a diligent and hardworking person, and she is requesting a 1,500,000 MNT loan to purchase more winter clothing items for her business.

loans.use: To purchase more winter clothing items.

loans.name: Twelwaneku Development Group-Jinja

texts.en:
G. Betty’s ten-year-old beauty salon and hairdressing enterprise is one she speaks of in the highest and most glowing of terms. The business has been indispensable in making ends meet. Her business generates a weekly income of 50,000 UGX. Betty undertook apprentice training at a local salon and this molded her into the beautician that she is today.
Betty is happily married with five children. Casting her mind back, she says her first business experience was in a farming enterprise.
With this loan, she will purchase more hair chemicals for her salon business. Betty belongs to Twelwaneku Development group-Jinja.

loans.use: To purchase more hair chemicals for her salon business

loans.name: Kisakyamaria Group-Jinja

texts.en: N. Betty is 45 years old and a member of KisaKyamaria group-Jinja. For ten years, Betty has been running a charcoal sales business in Jinja central market. Her customers are principally market vendors, hotel owners and restaurant owners. Betty, who is married with no children, says it’s a business she began with no prior experience. By her own account, she is a stickler for diligence. With this loan, she wants to purchase more bags of charcoal for resale.

loans.use: To purchase more bags of charcoal

loans.name: Safia's Group

texts.en:
Safia was married 21 years ago to M. A. who is a private entrepreneur and is in the business of selling cooking oil. He sells oil packets and oil cans to his customers on demand. He has been operating his business from a shop in the market for over 5 years.
  
Safia is a housewife who stays at home and does her household tasks. She has given birth to 3 sons. Her eldest son has passed the 5th grade and helps his father in his business by handling her husband's shop in his absence and by serving his customers without complaint. Safia's two younger sons are enrolled in school and are getting their education. With her family, Safia has lived in the city of Gujranwala, in an area named Faqirpura, for over 10 years.  

Safia has applied for a loan for her husband's business from Kiva partner Asasah. She is a new loan applicant of Asasah. Her husband will use the loan to purchase cooking oil in larger quantities and sell it through his shop. Safia is hopeful that through this investment her husband’s business will grow and earn him more income. She is very hopeful about the good outcome of her husband’s business. 

[Note: In the photo, the lady in the center holding a book (called the Asasah Passbook) in her hands is Safia.]

loans.use: To buy cooking oil in larger quantities for selling

loans.name: Anonymous Group
loans.use: To buy a new shop

loans.name: Sughran Muhammad Ilyas' Group

texts.en:
Sughran is a resident of Gujranwala where she lives with her family in a two-roomed brick house in an area named Faqirpura. She has been living here for over 30 years. Gujranwala is an industrial city also known for its rice crop.
Sughran supports her family by doing embroidery work for her neighboring customers. She has a vast knowledge of her business and keeps up to date about the latest trends in fashion. She is the mother of two daughters and a son. Her daughters help her in completing embroidery orders on time and her son works in a factory earning a meager income.
Sughran is married to M. I., a cobbler. He receives orders from different factories and shoe shops and provides them with finished goods to earn an income.
Sughran has applied for a loan from Kiva partner, Asasah, for her embroidery business. With the loan, she will buy embroidery materials such as beads, colored thread, fabric and sketches that will help her to finish orders on time and offer more variety to her customers. She is a new loan user of Asasah and this is her first loan application. She hopes that it will be a profitable experience for her.
Note: In the photo, the lady who has holds a book (called the Asasah passbook) in her hands is Sughran.

loans.use: To buy embroidery materials

loans.name: Anonymous Group
loans.use: To expand his business

loans.name: Alinhinkira Women's Association-Jinja Group

texts.en:
N. Joy is affliated to Alinhinkira Group-Jinja. She is happily married with nine children. The trade of welding has mostly been a male preserve, but it is fascinating that in today’s Uganda you will find women who are eager to turn a hand to even the hardest of jobs, which often involve a lot of elbow grease. Joy has been involved in this trade for ten years now. Her operating headquarters are in Ivunamb trading center-Jinja.
The need for self reliance, she says, is what got her started in this business. Her story of transformation from a housewife into a fully fledged businesswoman is something in which she takes pride. She says young underprivileged girls can look up to her and emulate her. Her weekly income is 70,000 UGX. Joy also runs a charcoal sales business. With this loan, she wants to purchase metal materials for welding doors, windows and chairs.

loans.use: To purchase metal material for welding doors, windows and chairs

loans.name: Sughran Bashir Ahmad's Group

texts.en:
Sughran lives in a two-roomed brick house in Gujranwala, an industrial city located in Punjab, Pakistan. She is a widow who had great difficulties after the death of her husband. She brought up her four sons and one daughter by doing labor in order to help them be successful in their professions. Her first three sons are cobblers by profession and make shoes by receiving orders from shoe factories and shops. Her youngest son is enrolled in school and is getting an education.
Sughran has applied for a loan from Kiva partner, Asasah, for her sons' cobbler business. With this loan, they will buy raw materials such as leather, nails and shoe polish in large quantities, which will help them to finish larger orders on time and make more income.
Sughran is hopeful that this loan investment will help her sons in growing their business and increasing their earnings. She is a regular loan user of Kiva partner, Asasah, and this is her fourth loan application. In previous loan years, she has maintained good credit behavior and attended every meeting.
Note: In the photo, the lady who has holds a book (called the Asasah passbook) in her hands is Sughran.

loans.use: To buy raw material for shoe making business

loans.name: Anonymous Group
loans.use: The purchase of more metal materials for her metal workshop

loans.name: Nguon

texts.en:
Nguon N., a 42-year-old resident of Kompong Chhnang Province, sells a few products such as soft drinks, food, and other plastic products. She typically makes around $2.5 of profit each day to ensure that her family has a comfortable living. She has been married for many years to Brak Khorn, 42, a man highly skilled at building stone and wooden houses. This couple has five children, two of whom are married while the other three are students and dependent on them.

Nguon wants her son to have an occupation as a motor-taxi driver; due to a lack of capital, she is requesting a loan from Kiva to buy a secondhand motorcycle for him to begin running a taxi service.

loans.use: To buy a secondhand motorcycle for her son to begin running a taxi service.

loans.name: Nelia

texts.en:
A loving mother, 44-year-old Nelia is very worried about her two children who still live with her and are dependent on her. Instead of letting herself be trapped by her insecurities, in 2008 Nelia joined Kiva partner, ASHI, in order to access a loan to allow her productive side to flourish. With previous loans, Nelia has developed a fishing business. Her profits augment her husband’s income as a fisherman and vendor. When her profits grow, she will be able to support her children’s education until they finish college. At that time, her role as a mother will be rewarded.
Nelia's relationship with ASHI and the loans she has taken since she became a member have helped her in running her business. Nelia has a solid repayment record, attendance record and business rating (credit rating), and this has qualified her for a higher loan amount. She is requesting a new loan to maintain her business by purchasing additional fish cages (fish traps) to catch more fish to sell in her neighborhood and nearby village.
Nelia's long-term goals are to expand her fishing business into a fish farm and give her children a brighter hope. She also hopes to provide other needs in order to enjoy the gifts of life that are full of blessing from almighty God and support from the good hearts of Kiva supporters.

loans.use: To purchase additional fish cages (fish traps)

loans.name: David Enguza

texts.en:
David J. aged 32 years is married to Lydia Kwamboka and together they have one child named Jane.He lives in Kangemi estate and his business is in the Nairobi Masai Market which is in the town centre. He sells  curios made of stone and also practises farming as his secondary business.

David who was introduced to KADET LTD by another Kadet client has been running this business for five years and he makes a monthly profit of Kshs. 6,000. Masai market is a very busy market so David  has been selling his curios both to locals and to tourists who have great interest in the market. With the loan he plans to buy more  curios for sale and with the extra income generated, he will expand his business. David is hard-working.

David's plan for the future is to buy a piece of land and build rental houses.

loans.use: To buy more curios and stone carvings

loans.name: Barnaba Kipchumba

texts.en:
Barnaba has operated his cereals store in Naivasha town for the last five years.  He is 44 years old, married to Tingo Salina, and they have four children.  

He was introduced to KADET LTD by his friend and this will be his second loan.  He repaid his previous loan well and in good time.  He plans to use the loan amount to buy more maize and beans for sale.

In future, Barnaba hopes to be supplying cereals in bulk in other major towns.

loans.use: To buy more maize and beans for sale

loans.name: Muira

texts.en:
Muira has been selling timber in Ndunyu Njeru town since 1984.  He is 45 years old, married to Milkah Wanjiru and they have six children.

He was introduced to KADET LTD by his friend and this will be his 3rd loan.  He repaid his previous loans well and in good time.  He plans to use the loan amount to buy more timber for sale as his stock is running low.

In future, Muira hopes to be a big supplier of timber in Ndunyu Njeru town.

loans.use: To buy more timber for sale

loans.name: Kong's Group

texts.en:
Four people make up this group loan. Mrs. Kong S. is a 32-year-old married woman and the group leader who was selected by the members of this group loan, located in Samraong K'aer village, Kandal province.

S. earns her living by operating two business ventures:  grocery selling and compact disk selling in the local market, which allows her to earn a little income to support the family. In order to increase her income to improve the family's living conditions, S. will use the loan that she asked for from AMK to buy more groceries and more compact disks to resell. S. is a widow with two children who are attending the local school.

loans.use: To buy more groceries and more compact disks to resell

loans.name: Chheang

texts.en: Chheang S. L. is 52 years old and she is a widow. She lives in Chamkar Doung village, Kandal province. She is a farmer who owns 1.50-hectare of land to cultivate rice for living. Aside from farming, she is a pig breeder. With her pig breeding, she faces a problem because she does not have enough money to support her breeding. Thus, Chheang S. L. would like to ask for a loan to buy pig food for her breeding busoness. The child who is in the picture is her grandchild.

loans.use: To buy pig feed for pig raising

loans.name: Maria Wangui

texts.en:
Maria has practised farming in Ndunyu Njeru town for the last 10 years.  She is 42 years old, married to Paul M., and they have seven children.

She was introduced to KADET LTD by her friend and this will be her first loan.  She plans to use the loan amount to buy potato seeds, fertilizer and pay for labour during planting. Ndunyu Njeru is a well-known place that has very good climatic conditions, really favovrable for potatoes and when planted in time they yield good results, so this makes  Maria work harder. 

In future, Maria hopes to practice  large-scale farming.

loans.use: To buy potato seeds, fertilizer and pay for labour during planting

loans.name: Touch's Group

texts.en:
Mrs. Touch P. is a 40-year-old married woman and the group leader, having been selected by the five members of this group loan, located in Anlong Ta Sek Leu village, Kandal province. 

She and her husband, Mr. Penh Vantha, are farmers who own a plot of land that they use to cultivate vegetables for a living. With the farm, they still can't earn enough income to support their family. Thus, P. wants to start a new business. She would like to ask for a loan to buy vegetables to sell; any remainder of the loan would be used to buy fertilizer to support her farming crops. This couple has four children: one is a construction worker and two are attending the local school while the other is just 4 years old and not in school yet.

loans.use: To buy vegetables to sell

loans.name: Marianette

texts.en:
Marianette A. owns and operates a business buying & selling fish and a fishing business in the local community. She has been engaged in her business for over five years and earns approximately 4,000 PHP a week. In 2007, she joined ASHI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and her ability to engage in entrepreneurial business activities. She has successfully repaid a previous loan from ASHI. 

Marianette is requesting a new loan of 25,000 PHP which will be used to invest in expanding her business. This loan will be her fifth from ASHI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve the general living conditions of her family.

Having this loan will provide her with a chance to achieve her dreams in life: to have a growing business, a good life, and a financial means of supporting her family and funding the education of her two daughters until they complete college in order to get better employment in the future. Her inspiration to offer a good life to her children fuels her to continue to dream, believe, and survive.

loans.use: to invest in expanding her fishing business

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To purchase electrical goods to sell in the store

loans.name: Wangeci Ngutha

texts.en:
Wangeci has been operating her retail shop in Ndunyu Njeru town for the last six years.  She is 44 years old, married to Ngutha N., and they have six children.

She was introduced to KADET LTD by her friend and this will be her first loan.  She plans to use the cash to add more foodstuffs such as flour, rice, etc. for her retail shop.

In future, Wangeci hopes grow from retail to wholesale.

loans.use: To buy more foodstuffs like flour, rice, etc.

loans.name: John Thuo

texts.en:
John has operated his butcher shop in Naivasha town for the last two years.  He is 48 years old, married to Elizabeth Waithera, and they have four children.

He was introduced to KADET by his friend and this will be his third loan.  He has repaid his previous loans well and in good time.  He plans to use the loan amount to buy more goats which he will rear, slaughter, and he will sell the meat later in his butcher shop.

In future, John hopes to operate a large restaurant in Naivasha.

loans.use: To buy more goats to raise for meat

loans.name: Paul Kimani

texts.en:
Paul has been in the  motorcycle  transport in Naivasha town since  the year 2008, and earns a good income.  He is 37 years old, married to Margaret Muthoni, and they have three children.

He was introduced to KADET by his friend and this will be his third loan.  He repaid both his previous loans well and in good time.  He plans to use the loan amount to buy new tyres, renew his PSV license, and buy a helmet for his passengers.

In future, Paul hopes to buy a minibus to operate in transporting people from one place to another.

loans.use: To buy new tyres, renew his PSV license, and buy a helmet for his passengers

loans.name: Chheun's Group

texts.en:
This village loan consists of thirteen members; Mrs. Chheun S., 63 years old, was selected as the village bank president by the members of this village loan, located in Dang Kdaong village, Kandal province. Each member of this group will use their portion of the loan to support their different businesses.

Mrs. Chheun S. and her husband, Mr. Chhun Moa, are farmers who own 1.50 hectare of land that they use to cultivate rice and corn for a living. Aside from farming, S. also earns her living by selling sugar cane juice in the local village. Right now she doesn't have enough money to support her farm. So, S. decided to ask for a loan to buy fertilizer and pesticide to cultivate rice and corn. This couple has three children: two are farmers and also help their parents on the farm while the other is a sugar cane juice seller.

loans.use: To buy fertilizer and pesticide to cultivate rice and corn

loans.name: Taraiya Ole

texts.en:
Taraiya has practiced farming in Naivasha town since the year 2005 and receives good returns from his agricultural activity.  He is 38 years old, married to Margaret Nchoi, and they have three  children.

He was introduced to KADET LTD by his friend and this will be his second loan.  He repaid his first loan of Kshs 25,000 well and in good time.  He plans to use the cash from this loan to buy pesticides and weed control, to spray on his farm.

In future, Taraiya hopes to own his own farming equipment instead of having to hire it every time he wants to plant or harvest.

loans.use: To buy pesticides and weed control

loans.name: Paulo

texts.pt:
Paulo B. nasceu em Chamanculo um dos bairros periféricos da cidade capital na década 70, pai de 2 filhos, um deles vai a escola. Fez 10ª classe e não continuou devido as dificuldades financeiras. Vive na casa própria com a sua família.

Nunca mudou de cidade, actualmente trabalha no Ministério da defesa como Musico instrumentista e tem um rendimento mensal fixo que aplica nas despesas de casa e ainda consegue poupar algum na sua conta bancária.

Foi através do seu serviço que soube da existência da Hluvuku e Ja solicitou 4 empréstimos aplicados na compra do terreno e materiais de construção para construir a sua moradia, o que melhorou a sua vida pelo que terá a sua própria casa onde vivera condignamente com a sua família.

Com o actual empréstimo e primeiro no Kiva no valor de 11.000.00mt pretende comprar materiais de construção (cimento, portas e areia) para continuar com a obra da sua casa.

O seu sonho futuro e de concluir a sua obra mobilar a sua casa e viver condignamente com a sua família e para tal, vai recorrer a mais empréstimos da Hluvuku/Kiva.
texts.en:
Paulo B. was born in Chamanculo in the perifery of Maputo, in the 1970s. He is the father of two children, one of whom is in school. His studies were interrupted in the 10th Grade due to financial difficulties. He lives with his family in a house they own.
